page.title: 11HISTORICAL OUTLINE
page.content: For most of its history,Sunderland was called Wearmouth.Prehistoric and Roman remains have been found nearby.It's history really begins in AD674 when Benedict Biscop set up on the north bank of the river the monastery of St. Peter.The church of which is still standing. It is the site of the first recorded glass-making in England,which is still very important in the town. Saint Bede was born and educated at St.Peter's.The north bank became known as Monkwearmouth whilst the south bank ,"sundered" from the monastery by the river was called Sunderland.To the west was the land of the Bishop of Durham,Bishopwearmouth. In 14th Cent shipbuilding and the export of coal began. In 1796 the largest single- span cast-iron bridge in the world was built across the Wear at Sunderland.
